bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, March 27, 1941

div1.p: Kellogg discusses the depiction of soldier volunteers in the Cornwell painting. He will test reactions to the painting in Cuba before distributing it.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, March 27, 1941
div1.opener:
Air Mail
257 CORNELISON AVENUE
JERSEY CITY, N. J.
March 27, 1941.
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Hotel Nacional
Havana, Cuba
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Your letter of March 21st written just before you left Rochester was much
appreciated. I decided that carrying those heavy color sketches of
Cornwall's would not be any great pleasure for you and hope that the
Kodachrome photographs of them turn out well and reach you in time for
them to be of some value on your trip.

I have had a very nice letter from General Kean who, I am afraid, is not
going to approve of the picture which Cornwall is painting. I am enclosing
a copy of my letter to him.

The common soldiers which we will include in the picture, while they will
in some way represent the four of whom we have photographs the likenesses
will not be so evident but what they will be representative of the
common soldier volunteers. They will appear as a group in the painting
and not as outstanding individuals.

Our export manager for South American countries just returned from Cuba.
After seeing the most recent sketch which I sent to you in Palm Beach he
said that he felt that the Cubans for the most part would receive the
painting most favorably. As he pointed out, the written copy which
accompanies the picture when sent to Cuba can make all the difference in
the world in their attitude toward the actual painting. We propose to
send a few copies to our friend, Dr. Kohly and let him try them out before
making any large scale distribution or before attempting to bring the
original painting to Cuba.

The other night when I was out in New York after having spent several hours
with Cornwall I believe I wrote both you and Mrs. Hench a postcard. I
hope I said the right things; I don't remember.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, George Kellogg George A. Kellogg
